data.title: Banger Parents: Prepare for Fubar 3, says director Michael Dowse
data.meta_description: In the Arts & Life section of today’s
data.text:
Reviews and recommendations are unbiased and products are independently selected. Postmedia may earn an affiliate commission from purchases made through links on this page.

Article content

In the Arts & Life section of today’s National Post

,

we have a great interview

with Paul Spence and David Lawrence, also known as Dean and Terry from the cult hit

Fubar

— and now,

Fubar 2

(which comes out this Friday). But our reporter wasn’t able to squeeze in all the quotes she got from director

Michael Dowse

, who was at TIFF to promote the film.

Here, below, are some extra tidbits from the Canadian filmmaker:

On the decision to make a sequel

:

“We didn’t want to tread the same ground all over again, but as time went on, there was more of a call to do a sequel and we said, ‘Well, let’s explore it and see what happens.’ We wrote something, we were pretty happy with it, and two years ago we got financing and went ahead. But we took that pressure from our fans pretty earnestly — none of us wanted to disappoint people and I don’t think we have.”

Article content

On filming near the contentious oil sands in Alberta

:

“We were just shooting from public roads, so we were free to shoot all of that. There’s no company signage, and besides, we were over 100 feet from a public road, which isn’t breaking any laws. But we came to the conclusion very early on that we’d never get clearance to get on that property, so we chose to have Terry and Dean work on a pipeline outside in the open air, as opposed to in an actual refinery or whatever. We also shot in Fort Saskatchewan, not in Fort McMurray. That was the only way we could do it. We also spent time in the editing room digitally erasing of a lot of logos.”

On making movies about jerks… lovable jerks, that is

:

“For me, I like characters that are assholes, but creative in how they’re assholes. With It’s All Gone Pete Tong

, it was a mix of Jeff Bridges in

The Big Lebowski

and Sean Penn in

Sweet and Low Down

, where the guy’s obviously talented but he’s an asshole — that’s what I gravitate toward. It’s easy to make someone sympathetic because his dad died or there’s some outside thing that does it; but it’s more of a challenge with guys like Terry and Dean. It would all fall apart if it wasn’t funny, that’s for sure.”

Article content

On carefully orchestrating all of the inebriated destruction

:

“That’s all carefully planned… it’s a safety issue. We wanted to open with a party and didn’t want it to feel like a beer commercial. Those nine minutes are there to answer the call of the sequel; it’s like a Bond film where you start with a huge action sequence and then get on with the main story. We wanted to fill the appetite of our fans.”

On newcomer Terra Hazelton, who plays love interest Trish

:

“Isn’t she amazing? Can you please focus on her and say in your writing how f—ing strong she is as an actress? She goes toe-to-toe with those guys and, man, she is just so good. She’d ever acted before, and on the first day, we stuck an M16 in her hand; two hours later we had her in a wave pool for three hours; then at the end of the day she’s in a motel hot tub with Dean. We just threw her into it.”

On the possibility of a third

Fubar

film

:

“I think there will be a third in our future, but it’s too early to know where and what. But there are two new members of the family now, so it would probably be sort of like, banger parents. That’s the next phase of these guys’ lives.”

On what he’s doing next

:

“I’m in prep on a film called Goon

; we start shooting Oct. 18th in Winnipeg. Jay Baruchel and Evan Goldberg wrote it. Basically it’s about a Jewish bouncer who’s touched by the fist of God and becomes an enforcer in a major hockey league.”
